notes: One of four seasons. Spring in Japan runs from March to May.

examples.japanese: 春だ！春が来たんだ！
examples.english: It's spring! Spring has come!

examples.japanese: 暖かい春からこの物語を始めることにしましょう
examples.english: Let's start this story in warm spring.

notes: Irregular verb. Past: 来た (きた). Te-form: 来て (きて). Imperative: おいで.

examples.japanese: 春が来たんだ！
examples.english: Spring has come!

examples.japanese: 今年はずいぶん早く帰ってきたね
examples.english: You came back pretty early this year.
examples.note: 帰って + きた (motion toward speaker)

examples.japanese: さあこっちにおいで
examples.english: Now come over here.
examples.note: おいで = polite imperative of 来る

notes: Intransitive verb. For 'to put to sleep,' use 寝かせる.

examples.japanese: ほらみんな眠っていますよ
examples.english: Look, everyone is sleeping.

examples.japanese: この谷の住民たちは冬の間眠って過ごします
examples.english: The residents of this valley sleep through the winter.

meaning: to wake up, to get up
notes: Intransitive. Compare: 起こす (to wake someone up).

examples.japanese: 起きたのね二人とも
examples.english: You both woke up, didn't you?

examples.japanese: やあミー君も起きてたのか
examples.english: Oh, Little My, you're awake too.

notes: A key item in Episode 1 - the mysterious magic hat.

examples.japanese: あれはシルクハットだ
examples.english: That's a top hat!
examples.note: シルクハット = silk hat / top hat

examples.japanese: この帽子パパのに似てるな
examples.english: This hat looks a lot like Dad's.

examples.japanese: 残念だけどこの帽子は大きすぎる
examples.english: Unfortunately, this hat is too big.

notes: One of four seasons. Moomin characters hibernate during winter.

examples.japanese: ムーミン谷は冬になるとすっかり雪で覆われてしまうんです
examples.english: Moominvalley gets completely covered in snow during winter.

examples.japanese: みんなが雪の下で眠っている冬から始めるわけにはいかないので
examples.english: We can't start from winter when everyone is sleeping under the snow.

notes: 冬 (winter) + 眠 (sleep). The Moomin family hibernates every winter.

examples.japanese: 私どうしてこの家で冬眠してたの
examples.english: Why was I hibernating in this house?

examples.japanese: 冬眠明けのお料理を作ることにしましょうか
examples.english: Shall we make some post-hibernation dishes?

notes: ムーミン谷 (Moomin Valley) is the setting of the story.

examples.japanese: みなさんはムーミン谷のことを聞いたことがありますか
examples.english: Have you all heard of Moomin Valley?

examples.japanese: この谷の住民たちは冬の間眠って過ごします
examples.english: The residents of this valley sleep through the winter.

notes: Common in winter scenes. 雪が降る = it snows.

examples.japanese: ムーミン谷は冬になるとすっかり雪で覆われてしまうんです
examples.english: Moominvalley gets completely covered in snow during winter.
examples.note: 雪で覆われる (be covered with snow)

notes: Also read as うち when meaning 'my house/home'.

examples.japanese: これはムーミンの家です
examples.english: This is Moomin's house.

examples.japanese: 私家でお姉ちゃんと一緒に寝てたはずだけど
examples.english: I should have been sleeping with my big sister at home.

examples.japanese: 僕が家を出た時ママは起きてました
examples.english: When I left the house, Mama was awake.

notes: 物 (thing) + 語 (speak/tell). A narrative or story.

examples.japanese: これがこの物語の主人公ムーミントロール
examples.english: This is Moomintroll, the main character of this story.

examples.japanese: それではさっそく物語を始めることにします
examples.english: Now, let's promptly start the story.

notes: Transitive. 始まる is the intransitive form.

examples.japanese: それではさっそく物語を始めることにします
examples.english: Now, let's promptly start the story.

examples.japanese: 暖かい春からこの物語を始めることにしましょう
examples.english: Let's start this story in warm spring.

meaning: to hear, to listen, to ask
notes: Versatile verb. Context determines meaning.

examples.japanese: みなさんはムーミン谷のことを聞いたことがありますか
examples.english: Have you all heard of Moomin Valley?

meaning: to see, to look, to watch
notes: One of the most common verbs. Te-form: 見て.

examples.japanese: うちに行ってお姉ちゃんが帰ってきてるかどうか見てくる
examples.english: I'm going home to see if big sister has come back.

examples.japanese: でも見てくる
examples.english: But I'll check.

examples.japanese: あなたは自分の顔鏡で見たことあるの
examples.english: Have you ever seen your own face in the mirror?

notes: One of the most common verbs. 〜と言う (called/named).

examples.japanese: この子は自分がムーミンだって言い張るんだよ
examples.english: This child insists they are Moomin.

examples.japanese: 言ったでしょ静かにしてって
examples.english: I told you to be quiet.

notes: Irregular te-form: 行って. Opposite of 来る.

examples.japanese: 君もスノフキンに会いに行くの
examples.english: Are you going to see Snufkin too?

examples.japanese: お兄さん私ムーミンのところに遊びに行っていい
examples.english: Hey, can I go visit Moomin?

examples.japanese: 去年の秋ミーのお姉ちゃんはお母さんのところへ行ったろ
examples.english: Last autumn, my big sister went to our mother, right?

notes: Used when returning to one's home/base. Compare: 戻る.

examples.japanese: スノフキンが帰ってる
examples.english: Snufkin is back.

examples.japanese: 今年はずいぶん早く帰ってきたね
examples.english: You came back pretty early this year.

examples.japanese: ミムラが帰ってくるまでミーはずっとこの家にいていいんだよ
examples.english: Until Mimura comes back, I can stay in this house forever.

notes: Common verb. 忘れ物 = forgotten item.

examples.japanese: 忘れちゃったの
examples.english: Did you forget?

examples.japanese: 4ヶ月も眠ると去年のことなんかみんな忘れちゃうんだなミーは
examples.english: If you sleep for four months, you forget everything from last year.

notes: 思い (thought) + 出す (put out). To bring out a memory.

examples.japanese: なんとなく思い出してきた
examples.english: I'm starting to remember a little.

examples.japanese: やっと思い出したらしいな
examples.english: It seems you've finally remembered.

notes: 覚える = to memorize/learn. 覚えている = to remember (know).

examples.japanese: 覚えてることだってあるわ
examples.english: There are things I remember.

notes: Basic size adjective. Adverb form: 大きく.

examples.japanese: ずいぶん大きいな
examples.english: It's quite big.

examples.japanese: これは私の帽子より大きいよ
examples.english: This is bigger than my hat.

examples.japanese: 残念だけどこの帽子は大きすぎる
examples.english: Unfortunately, this hat is too big.

notes: Can mean both intellectually interesting and fun/amusing.

examples.japanese: 僕たち面白いことをするんだ
examples.english: We're going to do something fun.

examples.japanese: 山に登るのは何が面白いのさ
examples.english: What's so fun about climbing a mountain?

examples.japanese: さあスニフを起こして何か面白いことをしようよ
examples.english: Now let's wake up Sniff and do something fun.

notes: Also written/pronounced さみしい. Describes emotional loneliness.

examples.japanese: お姉ちゃんがいなくて寂しいからって冬眠する前の日ここへ来たんだぞ
examples.english: I came here the day before hibernating because I was lonely without my sister.

notes: For weather/temperature. Also 温かい for emotional warmth.

examples.japanese: 暖かい春からこの物語を始めることにしましょう
examples.english: Let's start this story in warm spring.

notes: 早い (early/fast) vs 速い (speedy). Often interchangeable.

examples.japanese: 今年はずいぶん早く帰ってきたね
examples.english: You came back pretty early this year.

examples.japanese: 縄梯子より階段の方が早いわ
examples.english: It's quicker to take the stairs than the rope ladder.

examples.japanese: パパ早くこの雲に乗って
examples.english: Dad, quickly get on this cloud.

notes: Strong positive adjective. Very common in praise.

examples.japanese: 素晴らしい眺めだろスニフ
examples.english: It's a wonderful view, isn't it, Sniff?

examples.japanese: こんな素晴らしい天気だ
examples.english: The weather is amazing.

examples.japanese: 夢を追うということは素晴らしいことさ
examples.english: Chasing a dream is a wonderful thing.

notes: 残念ながら = unfortunately. Very common expression.

examples.japanese: 残念だけどこの帽子は大きすぎる
examples.english: Unfortunately, this hat is too big.

examples.japanese: 残念ねもっと遊びたかったのに
examples.english: What a shame, I wanted to play more.

notes: 本当に = really. 本当？ = Really? Very common.

examples.japanese: 本当に空飛ぶ船なんかできるのかな
examples.english: I wonder if a real flying ship can be made.

examples.japanese: 僕本当にムーミンなんだよ
examples.english: I'm really Moomin!

examples.japanese: ねえ本当にあんた誰
examples.english: Hey, who are you really?

notes: Casual form. More formal: お姉さん (oneesan).

examples.japanese: 私家でお姉ちゃんと一緒に寝てたはずだけど
examples.english: I should have been sleeping with my big sister at home.

examples.japanese: 去年の秋ミーのお姉ちゃんはお母さんのところへ行ったろ
examples.english: Last autumn, Little My's big sister went to their mother.

examples.japanese: うちに行ってお姉ちゃんが帰ってきてるかどうか見てくる
examples.english: I'm going home to see if big sister has come back.

notes: Casual: お兄ちゃん. Used for one's own brother or addressing young men.

examples.japanese: お兄さん私ムーミンのところに遊びに行っていい
examples.english: Hey, can I go visit Moomin?

examples.japanese: もちろんお兄さんは行かないわね
examples.english: Of course, big brother isn't going.

notes: Katakana word from English. ムーミンパパ = Moominpapa.

examples.japanese: そしてこれがムーミンパパ
examples.english: And this is Moomin Papa.

examples.japanese: この帽子パパのに似てるな
examples.english: This hat looks a lot like Dad's.

examples.japanese: どうしたのパパ
examples.english: What's wrong, Dad?

notes: Katakana word from English. ムーミンママ = Moominmama.

examples.japanese: これがムーミンママ
examples.english: This is Moomin Mama.

examples.japanese: きっとムーミンママが何かおいしいものを作ってるんだね
examples.english: Moominmama is probably making something delicious.

examples.japanese: 僕をムーミンって呼んでよママ
examples.english: Call me Moomin, Mama.

notes: 今 (now) + 年 (year). Compare: 去年 (last year), 来年 (next year).

examples.japanese: 今年はずいぶん早く帰ってきたね
examples.english: You came back pretty early this year.

examples.japanese: 今年あの山に登るのは僕たちが一番なんだぜ
examples.english: This year, we're the first ones to climb that mountain.

examples.japanese: 今年こそ僕は空飛ぶ船を作ってみせるぞ
examples.english: This year, I will definitely make a flying ship!
examples.note: こそ = emphasis (this year for sure)

notes: 去 (go away) + 年 (year). The year that has passed.

examples.japanese: 去年の秋ミーのお姉ちゃんはお母さんのところへ行ったろ
examples.english: Last autumn, Little My's big sister went to their mother.

examples.japanese: 4ヶ月も眠ると去年のことなんかみんな忘れちゃうんだな
examples.english: If you sleep for four months, you forget everything from last year.
examples.note: 去年のこと = things from last year

notes: Basic noun. 山に登る = to climb a mountain.

examples.japanese: 山に登るのは何が面白いのさ
examples.english: What's so fun about climbing a mountain?

examples.japanese: 今年あの山に登るのは僕たちが一番なんだぜ
examples.english: This year, we're the first ones to climb that mountain.

notes: Basic noun. 海へ行く = to go to the beach/sea.

examples.japanese: 海が光ってる
examples.english: The sea is sparkling.

examples.japanese: 海だってね
examples.english: And the sea too.

notes: Appears in the magic hat scene where clouds form from the hat.

examples.japanese: 何これ雲みたい
examples.english: What is this? It looks like a cloud.

examples.japanese: 僕も知らないようちの中から雲が湧いてきたんだ
examples.english: I don't know either, a cloud has emerged from inside our house.

examples.japanese: あらららら雲がなくなっちゃった
examples.english: Oh dear, the cloud has disappeared.

notes: 旅行 (りょこう) is more common for 'travel'. 旅 is more poetic.

examples.japanese: 南の方の旅はつまらなかったの
examples.english: Was the trip to the south boring?

examples.japanese: 旅の話をしてよ
examples.english: Tell me about your trip.
examples.note: 旅の話 = stories of the trip

notes: 話す (to speak) → 話 (talk/story). Very common word.

examples.japanese: 旅の話をしてよ
examples.english: Tell me about your trip.
examples.note: 話をする = to tell/talk about

examples.japanese: あとでゆっくりとね
examples.english: Later, slowly.

notes: Both sleep dreams and life dreams/aspirations.

examples.japanese: 夢ね兄さんは夢を追ってるんだわ
examples.english: A dream, huh? You're chasing a dream, brother.
examples.note: 夢を追う = to chase a dream

examples.japanese: 夢を追うということは素晴らしいことさ
examples.english: Chasing a dream is a wonderful thing.

examples.japanese: 僕食べ物の夢ならしょっちゅう見るよ
examples.english: Well, I often dream about food.
examples.note: 夢を見る = to have a dream

notes: 空飛ぶ船 = flying ship appears in Snorkmaiden's brother's dream.

examples.japanese: 今年こそ僕は空飛ぶ船を作ってみせるぞ
examples.english: This year, I will definitely make a flying ship!

examples.japanese: 本当に空飛ぶ船なんかできるのかな
examples.english: I wonder if a real flying ship can be made.

notes: Very versatile. Used for food, things, situations.

examples.japanese: 冬眠明けのお料理を作ることにしましょうか
examples.english: Shall we make some post-hibernation dishes?

examples.japanese: 今年こそ僕は空飛ぶ船を作ってみせるぞ
examples.english: This year, I will definitely make a flying ship!

examples.japanese: きっとムーミンママが何かおいしいものを作ってるんだね
examples.english: Moominmama is probably making something delicious.

notes: Used for vehicles, horses, etc. 〜に乗る pattern.

examples.japanese: 私も乗りたい
examples.english: I want to ride it too.

examples.japanese: パパ早くこの雲に乗って
examples.english: Dad, quickly get on this cloud.

examples.japanese: どうしたの乗りたければ乗せてあげるよ
examples.english: What's wrong? If you want to ride, I can let you.

notes: Used for birds, planes, jumping. 空を飛ぶ = fly in the sky.

examples.japanese: 子供たちのこと知ってるか空中を飛び回っているんだぞ
examples.english: Do you know about the kids? They are flying around in the air!

examples.japanese: ねえスナフキンさっき飛行鬼が飛んでるのを見たよ
examples.english: Hey Snufkin, I saw a flying goblin earlier.

notes: Intransitive. Transitive: 落とす (to drop something).

examples.japanese: 落っこちないように気をつけなさいって
examples.english: Be careful not to fall.
examples.note: 落っこちる = casual for 落ちる

examples.japanese: 落ちる落ちる死んじゃう
examples.english: I'm falling, I'm falling, I'm going to die!

notes: 山に登る = climb a mountain. 上る is similar but broader.

examples.japanese: 山に登るのは何が面白いのさ
examples.english: What's so fun about climbing a mountain?

examples.japanese: 今年あの山に登るのは僕たちが一番なんだぜ
examples.english: This year, we're the first ones to climb that mountain.

notes: General play. 遊びに行く = go to play/visit someone.

examples.japanese: お兄さん私ムーミンのところに遊びに行っていい
examples.english: Hey, can I go visit Moomin?

examples.japanese: 残念ねもっと遊びたかったのに
examples.english: What a shame, I wanted to play more.

examples.japanese: また一緒に遊ぼうさあおいで
examples.english: Let's play together again, come on over.

notes: 探す (look for) vs 見つける (find). Common pair.

examples.japanese: 地下室は探したの
examples.english: Did you search the basement?

examples.japanese: きっとあの帽子を探しているんだよ
examples.english: I'm sure it's looking for that hat.

notes: Intransitive. Transitive: 見つける (to find).

examples.japanese: 見つかった
examples.english: Found it.

examples.japanese: ムーミンがどうしても見つからないんです
examples.english: I just can't find Moomin.
examples.note: どうしても〜ない (no matter what)

examples.japanese: どうやら僕だけ見つからなかったようだね
examples.english: It seems I'm the only one who wasn't found.

notes: Intransitive. かくれんぼ = hide and seek.

examples.japanese: あのどこか隠れるところありませんか
examples.english: Is there anywhere to hide?
examples.note: 隠れるところ = place to hide

examples.japanese: 君はムーミンがどこに隠れているか知っているのかい
examples.english: Do you know where Moomin is hiding?

notes: 知っている = know (state). 知らない = don't know.

examples.japanese: 僕も知らないよ
examples.english: I don't know either.

examples.japanese: おい知らないぞ落ちたって知らないぞ
examples.english: Hey, I don't know! If you fall, it's not my problem!

examples.japanese: 子供たちのこと知ってるか
examples.english: Do you know about the kids?

notes: 分かった = understood/got it. Very common response.

examples.japanese: 分かったわ分かったから少し黙って落ち着いてちょうだい
examples.english: I understand, I understand, so be quiet and calm down a little.

examples.japanese: ママのこと分かってるんでしょ
examples.english: You know who Mama is, right?

notes: 〜を待つ = wait for. ちょっと待って = wait a moment.

examples.japanese: おい待て降りてこい
examples.english: Hey, wait, come down!

examples.japanese: おい待て僕の雲待ってくれ
examples.english: Hey wait, my cloud, wait for me!

notes: 〜と呼ぶ = to call (by name). 呼んで = call me.

examples.japanese: ムーミンって呼んで
examples.english: Call me Moomin.

examples.japanese: どうして僕のこと呼んでくれないの
examples.english: Why won't you call me?

notes: Common verb for disposing of things. ゴミを捨てる = throw away trash.

examples.japanese: それじゃあ捨てちゃおうか
examples.english: Then shall we throw it away?

examples.japanese: 拾ったものを捨てただけさ
examples.english: I just threw away what I picked up.

notes: Masculine first person. Used by boys and some adult men.

examples.japanese: 僕はムーミントロール
examples.english: I'm Moomintroll.

examples.japanese: 僕たち面白いことをするんだ
examples.english: We're going to do something fun.

examples.japanese: 僕本当にムーミンなんだよ
examples.english: I'm really Moomin!

notes: Neutral/feminine first person. Most common for women.

examples.japanese: 私どうしてこの家で冬眠してたの
examples.english: Why was I hibernating in this house?

examples.japanese: 私も乗りたい
examples.english: I want to ride it too.

examples.japanese: 私が自分の子供を間違えるはずはありません
examples.english: I would never mistake my own child.

notes: Informal. More formal: 皆さん (minasan).

examples.japanese: ほらみんな眠っていますよ
examples.english: Look, everyone is sleeping.

examples.japanese: みなさんはムーミン谷のことを聞いたことがありますか
examples.english: Have you all heard of Moomin Valley?

examples.japanese: さあさあみんなお食事しましょうね
examples.english: Alright everyone, let's have a meal.

notes: Location demonstrative. ここ/そこ/あそこ (here/there/over there).

examples.japanese: 私しばらくここにいてもいい
examples.english: Can I stay here for a while?

examples.japanese: ここにいるよ
examples.english: I'm right here.

notes: Mid-distance demonstrative. Near the listener.

examples.japanese: そんなものできるもんですか
examples.english: Can such a thing really be done?

notes: Far demonstrative. Distant from both speaker and listener.

examples.japanese: あそこからムーミン谷が全部見えるぞ
examples.english: From up there, you can see all of Moominvalley.
examples.note: あそこから = from over there

examples.japanese: あそこ
examples.english: Over there.

notes: Read なに before consonants, なん before d/n/です.

examples.japanese: 何だろうこれは
examples.english: I wonder what this is.
examples.note: 何だろう = what could it be

examples.japanese: 山に登るのは何が面白いのさ
examples.english: What's so fun about climbing a mountain?

examples.japanese: 何を
examples.english: What?

notes: Question word for people. 誰か = someone.

examples.japanese: 誰かが落としていったんだろう
examples.english: Someone must have dropped it.

examples.japanese: 君は誰だ
examples.english: Who are you?

examples.japanese: 誰だここでゆで卵を食べたのは
examples.english: Who ate a boiled egg here?

notes: Question word for place. どこか = somewhere.

examples.japanese: どこ
examples.english: Where?

examples.japanese: ムーミンおまえは一体どこに隠れていたんだ
examples.english: Moomin, where on earth have you been hiding?

examples.japanese: あのどこか隠れるところありませんか
examples.english: Is there anywhere to hide?

notes: Superlative marker. 一番好き = like the most.

examples.japanese: 今年あの山に登るのは僕たちが一番なんだぜ
examples.english: This year, we're the first ones to climb that mountain.

examples.japanese: やっぱりムーミン谷が一番だからね
examples.english: After all, Moominvalley is the best.

notes: 今日 (today), 今週 (this week), 今月 (this month).

examples.japanese: 今はいないわね
examples.english: He's not here now.

examples.japanese: 今誰か笑わなかったかい
examples.english: Didn't someone just laugh?

notes: Context-dependent. もう一度 = one more time.

examples.japanese: もう一回だな
examples.english: One more time.
examples.note: もう一回 = one more time

examples.japanese: もう帰らなくちゃ
examples.english: I have to go home now.

examples.japanese: もう降りたほうがいい
examples.english: You should probably come down now.

notes: まだ〜ない = not yet. まだいる = still here.

examples.japanese: あいつはまだ寝てるよきっと
examples.english: He's probably still asleep.

examples.japanese: まだ帰ってないと思うよ
examples.english: I don't think she is back yet.

examples.japanese: 僕はまだ眠いよ
examples.english: I'm still sleepy.

notes: Emphasizes degree. Similar to すごく (casual).

examples.japanese: だからパパの書く物語はとても長い長いものになりそうでした
examples.english: That's why the story Papa writes seems to be quite long.

notes: Also used as softener: ちょっと待って. Very common.

examples.japanese: ムーミンちょっとこっちにおいで
examples.english: Moomin, come here for a moment.

examples.japanese: ムーミンはしかし心の中でちょっぴり惜しいなと思いました
examples.english: However, Moomin felt a little regretful inside.
examples.note: ちょっぴり = a tiny bit

notes: Emphasizes duration or degree of comparison.

examples.japanese: ミムラが帰ってくるまでミーはずっとこの家にいていいんだよ
examples.english: Until Mimura comes back, you can stay in this house forever.

notes: General interjection of realization or agreement.

examples.japanese: ああ楽しかった
examples.english: Ah, that was fun.

examples.japanese: ああ待て
examples.english: Ah, wait!

notes: Used to prompt action or express uncertainty.

examples.japanese: さあ降りなさいムーミン
examples.english: Now, come down, Moomin.

examples.japanese: さあこっちにおいで
examples.english: Now come over here.

examples.japanese: さあスニフを起こして何か面白いことをしようよ
examples.english: Now let's wake up Sniff and do something fun.

notes: Casual greeting. Masculine.

examples.japanese: やあミー君も起きてたのか
examples.english: Oh, Little My, you're awake too.

examples.japanese: やあ
examples.english: Hey.

notes: Very common in casual speech. すごく as adverb.

examples.japanese: わあ素敵
examples.english: Wow, amazing!

notes: Used as warning: 危ない！= Watch out!

examples.japanese: 危ない触るな爆発したらどうするんだ
examples.english: It's dangerous, don't touch it! What if it explodes?

examples.japanese: 早く乗らないと危ないパパ
examples.english: You have to get on quick, it's dangerous, Dad!

notes: Children's game. かくれんぼをする = play hide and seek.

examples.japanese: かくれんぼよ
examples.english: It's hide and seek.

examples.japanese: ムーミンはかくれんぼの天才ね
examples.english: Moomin is a hide-and-seek genius, isn't he?
